reviewText: If you are looking for a good movie to buy or even to rent...this is a movie to consider.  I was one of the many that watched Fireproof first, then to find out that the Sherwood church made two other films, so I backtracked.  I rented Facing the Giants and then came to Flywheel.  Since buying it only a few months ago, I've watched it over and over again.  Jay Austin is the every man.  He is dishonest in his business( a used car lot) and even over charges the minister at his church.  Even though going to church seems like a chore more than anything else.  He has a wife, Judy, and a son, Tod.  Judy knows that Jay can do better and Tod doesn't want to grow up to be like his dad.  But in a moment of self realization he gives his life to God.  God can do amazing things in your life if you let him.  The first half of the film is the set up for the second half.  Shot on a small budget, it still made big changes in my faith.

reviewText: This was a lot better than I expected! It's the first of three films produced by a small church in Georgia. The story makes sense and flows well. A car-dealership owner has a history of cheating customers to make a profit and he trains his two salesmen to do the same. After he accepts Jesus as his Savior, he realizes he can't do that any more. He's faced with foreclosure and his two salesmen quit. How the Lord helps him is a real encouragement. One black woman who he cheated and tries to make amends to steals the show in the last part of the movie. Great story!!

reviewText: I may never buy a used car from a dealer again after all I learned about the industry from this movie. I learned some valuable lessons, not just about used car sales, but also about priorities, through this funny and worthwhile film. It's not a polished, high-budget motion picture, but the story makes it easy to overlook its less important flaws. The movie gave us plenty to talk about with our kids, which is more than I can say for most other movies, and none of us were disappointed (ages 11 to 45).

reviewText: A couple things jumped out at me as I watched this movie late one night.  One was the Biblical admonition to step out in faith and the second was the Biblical verse that the Lord works all things for good to those who love him.Unlike so many low budget religious theme movies, this movie is actually well made. And here in 2008 when so many people are dealing with losing homes, jobs, higher fuel and food prices, its a great movie to remind those who profess a faith in the Lord, to be reminded that he wont let us down.  That he will make sure that our enemies are shown to be who they really are.Like the Bible verse about no weapon formed against us can prosper.  Its an honest, storyline about admitting we are wrong and asking the Lord to be #1 in our lives. Easier said than done, sometimes, when one fears that things will only get worse.And I loved the strong family, ethical, moral theme. This was a man about to lose his business, had a pregnant wife at home, and a former worker who didnt like his change of heart decision to turn the business over to the Lord.Then imagine how you would handle making right, bad choices, you had made earlier, which involved thousands of dollars.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Alex Kendrick plays Jay Austin, a used car salesman whose business and life are falling apart. In a moment of desperation and clarity, Austin decides to turn his life and will over to God with unbelievable results. In this first film by the Kendrick brothers (Facing the Giants, Fireproof, Courageous), the production values aren't top-shelf but the film still looks great and the content is perfect for the whole family. Scene after scene is heartwarming and poignant, or just plain laugh-at-loud funny. It's also a great tale of the morals and ethics that could serve as a lesson to all of corporate America by demonstrating what it means to go from being dishonest to honest in one's professional life. I can't say enough good things about it and I recommend the film for all ages.
summary: Wonderful tale of faith and ethics

reviewText: This is the movie that started it all. The folks at Sherwood Baptist started their movie production with this. If you liked Facing The Giants...you will enjoy this movie as well. It is about a used car salesman coming to grips with what and who he is. It doesn't have the football action of Giants, but it does have a fantastic story line and includes all of the elements that make a good movie. It is believable, humorous and is bound to make an impact. Men will like this movie, but it will challenge them.The only time it bogs down is well into the story. I can't tell you where without giving away the plot. Suffice it to say bogs down, NOT slow. It moves at a good pace and has a great deal to say.The cinematography is a little lacking, but it was done with commercial grade digital equiptment; with that in mind it is nothing short of miraculous. I watch a great deal of Independant Film. This looks as good as most of what you would see at a indy festival.Even though it is somewhat predictable, it does have twists. In fact I thought it better than Giants in primary plot. It is well worth the $12-$15 and I hope Sherwood pictures continues to produce wholesome, life changing stories.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Alex Kendrick had a vision.  Well, maybe not in the mystical sense, so let's just say he had a story to tell.  The story is about a used car dealer who fits the cliches about that line of work just perfectly.  Then one day his conscience starts to nudge him toward a more honest life.  He turns his business over to God, and says that since it belongs to Him, He's now responsible for how his new honest approach turns out.Radical move.  And of course it works out for him.  It's a sweet story with some hilarious moments, and it becomes that rare low-budget movie that works in spite of its limitations.  The "acting" in this film is strictly dinner theater stuff, not much professionalism to it, and the look of the production has nothing on any cheapo cable movie of the week.  But the story and its execution are spot on target, and that easily makes up for its shortcomings.  In fact, by the end of the film you'll be charmed by its shortcomings.  Kind of a "Breaking Away" for 21st century Christianity.Kendrick wrote, directed, and starred in the film, and also had a hand in the musical score.  I believe he had some help from above as well.  "Flywheel" has become a breakout hit in the hidden world of Christian cinema, and for good reason.  Very nice.

reviewText: My husband went to Heaven 5 yrs ago. I am raising our 11-yr-old son by myself. Some days I just want to give up, because it is so hard to touch this boy's heart and help him see WHY anyone would want to submit every area of his life to a God who took his Dad away. He wonders why he should allow someone else to boss him around because it would make him feel like a slave.I picked this movie based on the reviews here. I have turned off our cable TV service, and I've been feeding his mind with good movies about God and about men in history who have led exemplary lives. It is so easy to grade ourselves on a curve, based on the lukewarm integrity and devotion to God of most of the people around us. I want my son to see what a truly sold-out-for-God man looks like. How he lives his daily life and makes the hard choices. How his actions are honorable even when no one is looking at him. And most of all...WHY a man would choose this life of servanthood to God.I loved this movie. I laughed my fanny off. My favorite part was when one of his older customers gave him an attitude adjustment for cheating her, lol. I cried through the entire movie. It was so touching. I also made compromises that I thought I could live with when I was a younger Believer. And I, too was wrong about that and had to face the humiliation, confess publicly, and make things right. Nothing in my life has ever been harder to do.I was absolutely shocked when my son gave this movie a 10. Maybe something he saw will stick in his mind and lead him to Jesus for life. I could give no greater gift to my husband...or to myself. To those who made these movies, thanks from the bottom of my heart. Keep doing it!!!~Connie
summary: ~ It has it all...laughter, tears, a message that will convict and encourage

reviewText: Flywheel is one of the earlier movies from the folks who didFacing the Giants,Fireproof, andCourageous.  Although it obviously has a little less of the "big picture polish" that the later movies have (something that Alex Kendrick admits at the start of the movie), the Christ-centered message is just as strong.  Many of the same actors star in this movie as well - including the actress who plays the wife in "Giants" in a short background cameo at the end of the movie.  Not being a salesman, I can only imagine the pressures that are placed on these people to wring every last cent out of a customer - a hard field for a Christian to shine in.  I especially enjoyed the end of the movie - although I don't want to give it away.  Great movie!

reviewText: After seeing "Facing the Giants," then going to the theater to see "Fireproof," and subsequently also buying that DVD; I had to also see the initial effort by the Sherwood Baptist Church in Albany, Georgia.The intent of this movie was to be a ministry outreach to their community, and the goal was to show it in a local theater for one night. It ended up being shown for weeks, being shown elsewhere, and then released on DVD. Its success led to the production of the two later projects.If you are going to judge it alongside Hollywood productions- yes, the quality is not on the same level; yes, the writing is not on the same level; yes, the acting is not on the same level; and yes, the production values are not on the same level. But, it's still not bad- especially for a first-time effort by a group of amateurs. And believe me, I've seen plenty of larger-budget movies by Hollywood professionals that were much worse.You have to realize, that although the intent of this movie is to entertain; the heart of it is to minister. At the time when Mel Gibson's "Passion of the Christ" was released and became a blockbuster, and more religious-themed movies began being to be produced, it was said that the movie theater was becoming the new church. Let's face it, the past efforts of Christian movies, produced by Christians, have left a lot to be desired. But with "Flywheel" the bar was raised.As a Christian, knowing that this is a message movie, I watched it with "spiritual" eyes, so I was able to overlook its inadequacies. There is such an anointing on this movie, and it is very apparent that the Sherwood Baptist Church is yearning to bring glory to God, and to lift up Christ.Even so, I don't believe it will turn-off non-Christians, because it isn't preachy. The Godly values that the movie portrays is really just a demonstration of ethical living and doing the right thing. The movie is a witnessing tool, because it shows that you can preach a better message with your life, and not just your lips. In other words, actions speak louder than words.The goal for any Christian is to live a Godly life, and although many times we fall short, God's grace is sufficient. It's not about religion- it's about relationship. The movie shows what happen when we reach out to our Heavenly Father and are sensitive to what's in His heart. It's not about us. This movie shows what happen when we put aside what we want in order to do what God wants.We sing for God to Bless America, but why would He, if we're not willing to bless God in word and deed. The Sherwood Baptist Church is doing that with "Flywheel" and continue to do so with "Facing the Giants" and "Fireproof." If you're a Christian and you haven't seen all of these movies- you need to. Not only for the simple fact that they will bless you- but also to support this ministry. If you're not a Christian- these movies offer a practical demonstration of how God wants to work in our lives and our hearts, and how He wants to interact with us in a very real way.

reviewText: When I heard that this film was made for $20,000 I had VERY low expectations. It was suprisingly good. The cinematography is a bit rough (think a college film project) but in some ways it added to the "real world" feel of life in middle America, dealing with profound questions of business ethics, morality, parenting, and how faith, specifically Christianity, intersects with life. I actually thought this film was a whole lot better than "Facing the Giants", produced by the same outfit (with a much larger budget).
summary: Suprising good for a very low budget film

reviewText: I bought this just so I'd had a big enough purchase to get free shipping on the books that I was ordering. I don't remember which books I got, but I won't forget this film. Sure it doesn't contain top cinematography or acting. It won't appeal to a worldly person because there is no real action. The amount of emotion displayed is not even significant. The amount of emotion generated was though. I had tears in my eyes and a chill down my spine for several minutes watching a man choose to follow God no matter what the outcome. I enjoyed it just as much, if not more, than Facing the Giants - and I'm a big football fan. Putting this together on a $20,000 budget was nothing short of miraculous.Donald James ParkerAuthor of Love Waits

reviewText: For those who enjoyed "Facing the Giants," this is an earlier production made by the same Georgia church on a shoestring budget -- but still well done. This is the moving (and sometimes funny) story of a cheating, morally bankrupt car dealer who is behind on his bills. A spiritual experience leads him to re-evaluate his dealings in surprisingly different ways. Like "Giants," this film is better than you would expect considering the budget and is proof you don't need millions to entertain or move people. Film was run at Georgia area movie theater and shocked the church with the attendance, which prompted longer and wider play in the theater's chain. Obviously, success of "Giants" appears to be prompting a national release of this film by Sony, but that's a good move. I was looking for an older DVD, but I'll wait for the new release.
summary: Great spirtual film from "Facing the Giants" creator

reviewText: This is a film that inspires one to conduct their business and financial affairs with integrity. It reminds me of a story in the Bible where this tax collected indicated to Jesus that he would return double to all that he had swindled. At that statement, Jesus then proclaimed that salvation had come to that household. In this film Jay, decides to pay back the over-priced portion of the price to the owners of cars that he swindled them with in his dealings. The responses from the used car purchasers were really hilarious.So although Jay was going to church, he was really 'robbing' God as well as his customers. But at some point, he gets serious with God and stops the financial underhandedness.Salvation really then comes to his business and his family. This is a great family film that will inspire businessmen to be financially straight with God and with their fellowman

reviewText: This was the first film created by the Sherwood Baptist church in Albany, GA. Recent movies released in theatres were "Fireproof" and "Facing the Giants".This is about the director's cut, but I also have the full-length version. Looking at both, there's only about 5-6 minutes that were trimmed. Some missing bits are:- when Jay's flipping through the TV, a few of the channels he passed-by are not there- when Jay's wife asks if it's okay if they just have fruit for dinner- the church service had more scenes of praise from the congregationThese + others that I didn't mention (and maybe didn't notice) were nothing major and didn't take away any important story parts.My full-length copy is on two DVDs, with one containing the extras. All the extras that were on that are here. The new extras on this single-DVD include a commentary, subtitles, an 8-part Bible study with clips from the movie, and a few additional outtakes.The commentary was informative and fun. Most everyone working on the project knew of one another and it was interesting hearing about them; the locations used; etc. I learned:- they actually lost 30 minutes of the final edit a week or so before the film was to premiere and it had to do it all over again; it was completed about 4 hours before the premiere time and that was rough for 'em- the baby you see at the end of the movie is the actual baby that was in the lead actress who was pregnant at the start of the film- when Jay slammed his hand on the kitchen table and yelled at his wife while they were eating, the reaction from the wife is taken from when her actual husband yelled the lines to her- it was made under $20,000; about $15,000 was donated from various members of the church- the frozen pizza that was served one night at dinner was to represent the lack of creativity in the lives of the married couple (something silly said lightheartedly by the two commentators having a laugh)This DVD has improved sound quality and color correction, as stated on the package, and that is true. I could hear the dialogue much easier. All in all, this is the one you'd want to have for the most features.*****I wanted to say something about comments from one of the 1-star reviewers.Part of it contained: "This is a story of how a wicked man somehow has a miraculous change of heart, but we are never shown how, except for some prayer and religious TV watching. Here the message is unclear."What? When Jay heard his son telling a friend that he didn't wanna be like his dad; when Jay's recent victim, a Reverend, just bought a car and prayed that the Lord would "treat him just as he treated me today" & Jay opened his eyes while feeling uncomfortable; when one of the other car dealers told him "You taught me how!" on how to do what it takes to sell the used car; and when he happened to flip to the station that, right at that moment, was talking about how 'your marriage is in the state it is because of choices you've made'.All throughout various events, these were moments that were surely getting to Jay. Change in attitude can happen; people can decide...and Jay wanted better, especially with his family. He was selfish and not in tune with others...he realized it more...and desired to work on himself. It wasn't miraculous (like it was just instantaneous); it was a process.Another part: "This movie is the one of the most wicked I have ever seen. It is poison dressed as medicine. It is a lie dressed as truth. In this movie Christ is the missing flywheel that will make your life work. This is a lie. Christ is God Almighty; He made and maintains the universe and everything in it. He is King and Lord. He sits on the throne in Glory and disposes of all as He pleases. Christ is to be worshiped and obeyed. He is not a tool in our hands; we are objects He uses for His Glory (in heaven or in hell, see Roman 9)."Geez...it's a parable. The flywheel represents Jay's heart/manner. Easy. Of course Jesus is God and not a literal tool. "Without your flywheel, you're not going anywhere." the mechanic said to Jay. Without Christ, you're not going to be moving forward either. I could easily picture Jesus using a comparison such as this.*****OTHER THOUGHTS:- The car Jay gets at the beginning is not working and needs a new flywheel. After Jay gets right with God, the mechanic finds the flywheel the car needed. He said that he got it from someone for nothing and all he needed "was to ask"...and that's what we are to do: ask God- When Jay gives the title of the car to the woman who wants to return a vehicle since she can't pay the rest, Jay says it's "paid in full" -- which is, of course, what Christ did for us. His death and resurrection allowed mankind to be able to come to God and get spiritually back on track; Jesus' laying down his life for us allowed our sin-debt to be paid in full.*****Lastly, I wanted to mention that in 2005 I visited a mental-health adult day-program where clients learn social skills and whatever else they might need. I was pleased that there was a "spirituality" group. I was permitted to show "Flywheel" to those who wanted to be in this particular group. I remember certain clients getting very emotional -- including the pregnant caseworker -- and that it had a positive effect on them that day. There was laughter, tears, and it was a special moment. I'm thankful that I had the opportunity to do this and I give glory to God.
summary: humourous, serious, and enjoyable all in one package

reviewText: Note: I saw this movie at an event in the church i attend.I liked the main plot of the film: Used car salesman cheats customers...interesting, and there are several ways to go with a plot like that. but here are my main gripes with the film.the father/son aspect really bothered me. i think it's disgusting for a father to spend time with his son. frankly, i think that's gay. i had to turn away from the screen during those nauseating scenes.The use of a modern translation of the Bible in the film also really annoys me to death. I think that the King James Version is the best translation of the Bible-all post-1611 translations (niv, esv, nlt, lb, etc) are garbage and full of doctrinal errors.not only that, but the language of the KJV is brilliant and absolutely clear, whereas the niv, esv, nrsv, lb, nasb and other modern versions replace words and phrases, sometimes even substitutiing their own words. plus, the old is usually never better than the new...and in this case, the Old English in which the KJV was written in is far better than the so-caled updated English of the 21st century. most of the times, the language is dumbed down till it no longer sounds or even reads like the language of the Bible, but looks and reads like slang, which is totally disrespectful to the Word of God.Skip this movie altogether.
summary: Father/Son Aspect-Stupid. Modern Translation Of The Bible-Even Worse.

reviewText: Yes, this movie was the first one made by the people who brought you "Facing The Giants" and "Fireproof." And yes, each movie is better quality, which means this one, as the first, has the least quality. Nevertheless, this is still an entertaining movie. Considering it's a low budget by what some would consider amateurs, one needs to give them a round of applause.Yes, this movie has unbelievable moments. For example, the ending is a little unrealistic because of the time structure. Everything has a nice neat ending, though don't take it to mean that people who love God have no problems -- mainstream movies also make the same mistakes and have as neat endings. And most moviegoers prefer the nice neat endings!One side note. I thought the actress playing the wife looked familiar, and I told my wife that I thought we used to go to church with that actress. My wife wasn't sure it looked like her, but before the end of the movie, she agreed. Since going to church (in Tennessee together), my wife and I moved to Indianapolis and Tracey (the actress) later moved to Georgia. I guess I know what she's doing now.
summary: I hope my first movie would be this good

reviewText: I remember watching this film a few years ago, after reading about it and hearing about it in various media.  It is basically a morality play about a business owner, and whether or not he'll be ethical.It also shows some interesting family dynamics, and the importance of family on a person's life.  Religious faith is brought into the equation of the main character and the tough choices he must make.This movie is from the same creators who brought us "Facing the Giants", which is also a fine film.
summary: thought provoking, independent Christian film from Albany, GA..

reviewText: I've read other reviews about this flick and most will say what a good little first effort and how it compares with "Fireproof" or "Facing the Giants".  Even the director/star of this movie kind of apologizes for this movie only costing $20 or $25K to make... So, well, I must protest.  The other movies must be held up to "Flywheel".  This is the best of the lot as far as I'm concerned.  The stars of this movie are "every-men/women" who volunteered their time.  They acted like real folks...because they are real people, not actors and they did just great.  If any of you want the real dope on living Christianity, this is the movie to watch.  The subject was real.  The actors were real.  God was shown as a real God living in us if we decided to accept Him.  It is all the real deal.  Watch this and change your life forever!
Title: N/A

reviewText: As there are too many scales to evaluate on. Production vales were fine...nothing in it detracted from the tale being told. Acting, mostly pretty good; no need to single out those who didn't quite carry their load, but these are clearly not professionals. Script, surprisingly good. I was impressed by the clever and thoughtful approach to many sub-themes. And I laughed aloud many times.I am fully aware that this was made to be shown locally and remain a tiny adventure. And also aware that they tackled my question better in their later films. But though Jay's life really was spinning out of control, the decision to toss it all on the Lord just seemed too abrupt. I know people do make sudden transformations. However, as one who did not (I took longer than anyone I know.....glad I was given enough time to complete it!) I found the discarding of cynicism and callousness that were part and parcel of who Jay rather unlikely. I would think a guy like Jay would look to carrying a load of dope before he got on his knees.However, these guys are good storytellers. The flywheel metaphor is brilliant. Unseen, almost unnoticed, yet when out of whack nothing works properly. (As was the metaphor of fireproofing a marriage....good stuff.)Yet what makes this film really glow in my mind is its connection to "It's A Wonderful Life." Except that they would call it, "It Can Be A Wonderful Life." Once Jay commits, his life becomes better, not perfect (which is why it loses another half star; everything just does not go 180 degrees like this) but far better. And will be better EVEN IF THE THINGS ARE GOING BADLY. If I could write to the producers, I'd ask them to give us a tale with a bit more Job-like content. Those who believe do not always come out on top. The Christianity haters often seem to be doing great. But as the characters in this tale show us, life can indeed improve if you choose to align your life with the truth. Trust and obey, as the hymn says.So, not a Hollywood production, but I am honest when I say this is a legitimate 4 star film.
summary: A five star system really fails on this one
Title: N/A

reviewText: You might be tempted to turn this one off after the first ten minutes. Don't.Yes, the video quality and overall cinematography is rough around the edges and some of the acting is wooden (except for the principal character, Jay, played by Alex Kendrick). But if you stick with it, a touching, inspirational story unfolds, cleverly built around the used car lot of a salesman with dubious ethics who eventually sees the light and reforms.Janet Lee Dapper does a good job in the role of Austin's long-suffering wife. For car spotters, there are many handsome shots of a 1958, mint-condition Triumph TR30, a car coincidentally associated with the name Austin in real life.Unabashedly Christian and evangelical in its approach, there are a few clumsy moments, but all in all this is a worthwhile film. Alex Kendrick handled the direction, the music, and carries the story forward with an appropriate sense of humor and a credible portrayal of a godly man in crisis. A good family picture.Kudos to the church that put this together.

reviewText: My family thought this movie was ok, but it really touched my heart.  Honestly, I found myself crying through this movie mainly because I believe I serve a big God.  I know alot of people might think that the circumstances in this movie are beyond belief; however, the Bible is filled with beyond belief stories.  It is also the beyond belief things and circumstances that I look for my God to do.  I have never sold cars for a living, and neither would I want to.  However, my ex-wife belonged to a family full of car dealers and my grandfather was a car lot owner at one time in my life.  I know a good car dealer from a crooked one, and I know that alot of good people who have car lots have a hard time staying honest.  The circumstances in this movie just really hit home with me.  I believe that when the Bible said taste and see that the Lord is good that it meant what it said.  I believe if you put God to the test that everything will work to your good if you are seeking after him with all your heart.  I would definitely watch this movie again, I would recommend that others see it, and if I ever have a friend struggling to make it from day to day I believe this would be a nice gift for them.  God bless all.

reviewText: I am about to sit down with my wife and watch this movie for the third time. It has the same charm, humor, grace and positive Christian message that I have come to expect of the Sherwood Baptist Church/Kendrick brothers movies since I first saw Fireproof. Once again, the story is told of a person anyone can relate to, whose life changes remarkably for the better once they begin to let God run it.In Flywheel, used-car dealer Jay Austin is spiraling toward bankruptcy both financially and morally. He has lost sight of what matters and replaced wisdom with cleverness.Once he learns to turn control of his life and car lot over to God, the miracles that happen in his life are both believable and faith-building for the characters and the viewers.Please, Alex, Stephen, we want MORE!
summary: Faith is the flywheel that powers this film

reviewText: Made with a shoestring budget, "Flywheel" is an amazingly compelling story about the spiritual awakening of a dishonest used car dealer.  Jay Austin does everything he can to cheat and overcharge his customers, yet he is deeply in debt and is in danger of losing his car lot.  When he realizes that his marriage is falling apart and his son does not respect him, Austin finally decides to give his life to the Lord and let Him run the car lot.  This leads to peace for Jay and his family, but even more difficult financial situations for them.  The actors do a great job, and some of the best are those with small parts, such as the lady who berates Jay for his dishonesty when he comes to confess his shortchanging her in an earlier car sale.  This Georgia church family has found a unique ministry in producing entertaining and thought-provoking Christian movies which are very relevant for today.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Flywheel is a wonderful and very well done movie. In fact, it is much better than some "professional" Hollywood films. The message is very revelant as well and I just wish it was required viewing for every car dealer. If all businesses operated the way Jay Austin learned to, this would be a much better world. Thank you Sherwood Pictures and I hope you make many more films like Flywheel!

reviewText: The story is set in a used car lot, where we meet the owner, Jay Austen (Alex Kendrick), an unscrupulous and unhappy man. He cheats his customers and is a stranger to his wife and son. Then, a chance remark by one of his clients causes Jay to rethink his whole outlook on life.This was the first of the four movies (so far) made by the Sherwood Baptist Church in Albany, Georgia, and like the others, it is touching and inspiring. The photography may not be polished, but Alex Kendrick's film is solid entertainment. He wrote, directed, produced it, starred in it, composed for it, and did the cinematography and editing. Except for the camera equipment, everything was donated by church members, many of whom appear on-screen in the large volunteer cast. Though they are amateurs, they are very good and believable.This story of how a man is changed by God is a heartwarming one the whole family can enjoy together. The DVD extras telling about how the movie was made on a shoestring budget (only $20,000!) are fascinating. If you're a fan of the Sherwood movies, this is a must-have. Recommended.

reviewerName: MacGyver "With God, ALL things are possible!"
reviewText: "Flywheel" is the first movie from Sherwood Productions and stars Alex Kendrick- one of the people responsible for the more recent production (which is also awesomely excellent!  Either that or excellently awesome!) "Facing the Giants".In "Flywheel", you'll see some of the same actors and actresses and I thought it was neat how they were able to pull off different characters well.  Sure, they're all unprofessional unpaid amateurs, but they did a great job and got the message across.  There's not a lot of expensive sets or special effects in this movie- but the story is the most driving thing.Jay Austin is a used car dealer who fits every stereotype of sleazy used car salesmen out there.  He's an unscruplous dealer who cheats and rips off his customers- and teaches his employees to squeeze all the money they can out of each sale.  He has problems with his marriage because his wife disapproves of his dishonesty and his son doesn't want to be like him.  He also finds that he has to get enough money together to pay his mortgage quickly, as he's fallen behind on that.He goes to church with his wife after she nags him into it, but even there he puts in an empty envelope in the offering plate so others can think he gives a tithe.  The minister there decides to get a car from his for his daughter, and Jay rips him off too- though the minister thinks he's gotten a great deal.  When he prays for him and asks God to treat Jay just the way he's treated him, then we can start to see some things happening in Jay's life.When he finally gets to the point of realizing that He truly needs Jesus in his life and makes Him Lord- Jesus changes Jay completely and makes him into a honest man who sells his cars at honest and fair rates.  He's dedicated his car lot to the Lord and tries to honor God with it.And there's a lot more that happens because of that as we see how Jesus truly changes Jay's life and restores what was once broken.I definitely enjoyed this movie just as much as "Facing the Giants" and I would recommend it heartily.  There is a clear salvation message in this movie- and that's simply that Jesus loves everyone so much that He died for us and rose again- and all it takes to get to Heaven is to pray and make Him Lord and let Him make you into a new creature (2 Corinthians 5:17)  "Flywheel" presents a challenge to Christians to truly let Jesus be Lord over your whole life- including school, work, play, or wherever you find yourself.  And it presents a challenge to non-believers to really consider who Jesus is to them and where they stand with Him.Overall, it's a great movie with a clean, fun and funny storyline that has a serious message about the Lordship of Jesus and what He can do in our lives and it's highly recommended. Jesus is the Flywheel that keeps life going!
summary: Awesome movie that shows how Jesus changes people's lives!

reviewText: Flywheel is the first major film released by the creators of Facing the Giants and Fireproof.This church down in Georgia has a pair of brothers who enjoy making positive faith-based films.In Flywheel, Jay Austin is a used car salesman who will do anything to make a profit on selling cars. And because of that, his life is turning to trash.Once he turns his life over to Jesus, and changes his business habits, things start looking brighter.You can tell this film was made a while ago. And the technology used wasn't up to par with the rest of major motion pictures. The acting is a little stale and the message is a little skewed...As with Facing the Giants, we're taught that if we just give our life to Jesus, we'll get everything we've ever wanted. Everything will be amazing from then on out.This is so far from the truth. Giving your heart and life to Jesus will not make you rich.
summary: One Major Flaw And It's Theology

reviewText: I was kind of hesitating about watching Flywheel, but after renting it in late 2008, the movie is a definite part of my DVD library.It was the first movie made by Alex and Stephen Kendrick.  It tells the tale about an immoral and heartless car salesman named Jay Austin who lies to his customers just to make a buck.  When his marriage and his strained relationship with his son comes under fire, he realizes that he wasn't involving God in any of his business ventures.Through colorful and intellectual characters like Jay's wife, mechanics and a couple of his prior customers, the Lord uses them to have Jay to make amends not only with life on the homefront, but with his public life at the car dealership.Another part of what made this movie great is the message of God's intervention for our lives.  We must surrender everything before Him and allow Him to, as Jay Austin says, "be the boss".Sherwood Church in Georgia had the hands-on tasks of all of the jobs for this movie:  music score, costumes, production, etc.  That's what made me game to their ministry.Kudos to the Lord, the Kendrick Brothers and Sherwood Pictures for helping me to realize what we all have to do in this lifetime to honor and please God.Continue success and may the Lord bless you, your families and ministry.

reviewText: The nice thing about the director's cut is that right away they let you know the movie was made for about $23,000 and the production (film quality) is on the lowside. But, besides that the movie is really good. It shows how someone who has hit the low part of their life can turn themselves around and become a trustworthy person again. Jay Austen is a man who owns a used car lot. All he wants to do is make money to keep his family afloat, but his cheap standards (over pricing vehicles) are hurting everyone. He neglects his son, and fights regularly with his wife, until both son and spouse can't stand him. It does tend to go into faith very strongly at one point, almost to quickly. It seems there could be a slighter buildup to the character (Jay) deciding that faith is what he really needs. Though this scene shouldn't be a deterent because the movie is really good. Once Jay decides to become more truthful to his family, job and customers, the true power of faith is revealed. This company has also made the slightly better movie "Facing the Giants".
summary: Flywheel - great movie on faith and being truthful.

reviewText: I give this movie five stars for the story; original, honestly told and acted; the message that every father and businessman should take to heart; the simple yet clever plot; and the impact it has had on me. My faith has been given a serious heart massage! This same experience occurred after viewing "Facing The Giants", but not quite as much as this movie. The most likely reason is that I have a son the same age as the main character in the story. The actors, directors and production staff are all members of the same church and the unity of thought and purpose is evident! Praise The Lord! Another small reason (but worth mentioning)I loved the film is that it has a 'real' feel to it: the characters are 'normal' people found in every small town in America. How many movies have a used car salesman as the leading character? In addition, the shoestring budget reflects a production quality that I think is far more effective than if it was filmed with Hollywood money. I know I'm probably alone in that view, but oh well. So, do yourself a favor and buy this movie. You'll watch it over and over!
summary: Important message for fathers and businessmen!

reviewText: I found this on the shelf at Blockbuster and was surprised to find that it was an independently produced Christian film. This is a film about a less than ethical used car dealer who decides one day to start living his life with integrity and treating his customers fairly. The actors are amateurs but do a great job. There are some hilarious scenes in this film, some of them we find out on the commentary happened spontaneously and were unplanned by the film crew. The film looks good for a low budget though some scenes have the feel and look of a 1970s tv show. Don't let that keep you away. This is a great film for Christians and has a clearer message than the best selling book "Purpose Driven Life". I think a secular audience could enjoy this film as well as it dosen't "preach" at you per se, but tells the story of one man and his decisions. This is probably one of the best Christian films I have ever seen. A top notch effort by all involved. I look forward to their next film.

reviewText: I have seen Fireproof and Courageous and thought I'd watch Flywheel to see if it was as good as people said it was. I was pleasantly surprised at how funny it was. However this movie will also make you cry. It produces a roller coaster of emotions. The story is very basic but has some lovely twists and turns. This is really just a story about a man who takes advantage of other people and then decides to change his life by doing the right thing. I like that this movie has characters that you can admire. It is rare to find a movie like this in our modern world. This is a movie the entire family can enjoy.~The Rebecca Review

reviewerName: Rosemary Thornton "Niece of Murder Victim, Ad...
reviewText: I'm one of those people who seeks out the independently produced movies, as most of the mainstream movies hold little appeal for me. "Flywheel" is a small-budget film with unknown actors, but it's a first rate movie. I watched it one evening and was deeply inspired and touched by its message.Jason, the lead character (who owns the used-car lot) is very believable and he and the lot's mechanic were my favorite actors. They presented real and honest portrayals of men in today's world.Like all good literature and drama, this movie won't leave you where it found you! It is inspiring and elevating and the message remained with me for several weeks. The singular message this movie conveys is that prayer is a *powerful* force. Several times, I was touched to tears by this movie.Highly recommend for all ages and all people. And praise the heavens above, there's no foul language or violence or explosions. Imagine! A movie you can watch with your toddler and your grandma, without turning beet red from embarassment!
summary: Very well done and also touches the heart!

reviewText: I just finished watching Flywheel, the faith based movie about a corrupt car dealer.  This movie is absolutely fantastic.  After about half an hour into the movie you will feel tears emerging as you watch his transformation from dishonest car dealer to a Christ-centered businessman and a loving husband and father.You don't have to worry about foul language.  There is not one word of cussing, swearing, or irreverence to God.  No sex or violence or anything that you couldn't watch with the whole family.  You'll love this movie.  I will rate it G.

reviewText: I have to admit that it was a little difficult watching this movie AFTER having seen "Facing the Giants" on the big screen (3 times in a row!), seeing as how "Facing the Giants" has such extremely high production values & top-notch acting & music & all ...But, then again, the entire reason I sought the "Flywheel" DVD out (online & I didn't fail to note that it was already sold out in a ton of places ... ), was BECAUSE I loved "Facing the Giants" so much & I couldn't wait to see some of my favorite actors in action again (i.e. Alex Kendrick & the guy who played the vacillating coach [whose name escapes me at the moment] & some others that I had hoped to see again in "Flywheel") ...I do have to say, though, that the MESSAGE of "Flywheel" is awesome & there are some delightful scenes & brilliant acting scattered throughout & I also must say that I probably enjoyed the "Special Features" disc even MORE than the movie itself, just because it was so interesting to me from a wannabe Christian filmmaker's standpoint ...And, I might add, if you strip both "Flywheel" & "Facing the Giants" down to their most basic plotlines, then I think you will find essentially the same story told 2 different ways ...Which is why I therefore recommend, if at all possible, seeing "Flywheel" BEFORE seeing "Facing the Giants," because then you won't be disappointed by the lower production values of "Flywheel" ...Either way, I think BOTH movies (i.e. "Flywheel" & "Facing the Giants" [whenever it finally comes out on DVD]) are worth having in a family-oriented movie collection.********NOTE: IF YOU FOUND THIS REVIEW HELPFUL, THEN PLEASE GO & GIVE MY "THE LAST MIMZY" REVIEW A VOTE, BECAUSE IT IS CURRENTLY BEING SLAMMED BY FOLKS WHO THINK IT IS WRONG TO WRITE A MOVIE REVIEW FROM A CHRISTIAN PERSPECTIVE. AND, IF YOU'RE REALLY FEELING GENEROUS, THEN PLEASE ALSO VOTE FOR MY "DADDY'S LITTLE GIRLS," "UNACCOMPANIED MINORS," "APOCALYPTO" & "WE ARE MARSHALL" REVIEWS. (THINK OF IT AS A "RANDOM ACT OF KINDNESS" ;) THANK YOU! & LOTS OF HUGS & BLESSINGS TO ALL MY BROTHERS & SISTERS IN CHRIST <><
summary: If at all possible, see "Flywheel" FIRST!

reviewText: I borrowed a copy of this from a friend and promptly ordered a copy for myself. Ths is the best film I have ever seen for showing the fall and restoration of a Christian. As the daughter of a director who had two successful television series, I am somewhat picky on films. This one is so easy to follow and so well written, directed and acted that it is a joy. I was deeply moved by this story so real and so well suited to every true believer in Christ who has backslidden and the wonderful joy of restoration to fellowship with Christ. I also must say I have not seen such excellent photography. Each scene is started and finished with great care. It shows also how effective amateur actors can be when directed with care. I have since gotten a copy of the Fireproof and that is excellent for the showing of the conversion of the lost. I am looking forward to the newest film Courageous.

reviewText: This superb movie shows that millions of dollars are not necessary to make an excellent show.Jay Austin is a dishonest used car salesman.  He has his own lot and prides himself in his ability to rip off his customers.  While he is doing this, his life is falling apart with family problems, overwhelming debt, etc.A series of events brings him to his knees and he surrenders his life to the Lord.  Although it is very hard for him to stick with it at times, he is committed and sticks to his new life.  Things get tougher in many respects and his faith is tested.Although this picture is not one that cost millions to produce, it is better than most of the stuff put out by Hollywood.  It has some very powerful messages and may well produce some tears and goose bumps in viewers.  It is one that I would highly recommend to Christians.  It can also be enjoyed by non believers as it makes its points without being preachy.  Highly recommended!

reviewText: I enjoyed Facing the Giants, so I decided to rent Flywheel.  It's not bad.  Since it's Sherwood Baptist Church's first movie, and they were working with amateur cast and crew, I can forgive the camcorder type feel it has.  Aside from the lack of technical proficiency (which improved greatly during Facing the Giants), it's a fairly decent movie.  It felt a bit preachy (FTG was a lot preachier than this one), but I did like the fact that the main character's transformation seemed authentic.  In addition, although I'm not for the "gospel of prosperity," it is refreshing to see a movie that shows that sometimes miracles can happen when one truly commits him/herself to their God.  I also felt refreshed to see a movie without profanity, sexual inuendos (or explicit sex), and so forth.  I would feel comfortable showing this one (and FTG) to people of all ages.  Even though I don't necessarily believe the message both movies try to send (I'm not fundamentalist, but am more moderate in my theology), I am still relieved to see a movie that sends a positive message.  I hope their third film will have more of a mixed ending, instead of neat and tidy endings (like this one and FTG has), since life is more mixed than it is neat and tidy.  Still, kudos to the congregation/movie team for two good efforts.

reviewText: Flywheel (Director's Cut)I love this movie. It's the very first of 4 films that Alex Kendrick made from his quaint Baptist church in Albany, Georgia. I'm amazed how they made such an outstanding movie on a meager budget of only $20,000.The movie was intended to be merely a local outreach film. It gradually began to be shown in local theaters. The reviews were so high they ended up going nationwide in the theaters. Amazingly, what was put together by average folks with little money expanded.Next, they went on to make, "Facing the Giants"...one of my favorate movies of all time. This time the production quality was outstanding and you could see more cash was invested into the production. Next, came the movie, "Fireproof", which also received excellent reviews.Lately they came out with the movie, "Courageous". I bought it as soon as it hit the market. I've watched it at home alone and with friends about 8 times now. I never get tired of this movie. But that's another review.Flywheel is a greet movie and I will also have believing friends who enjoy watching it with me both now and in the future.
summary: The First in Several Good Movies...

reviewText: The fact that I hold in my hand a real movie made for twenty grand is a miracle in itself. Who says that you can't make quality entertainment without a multi million dollar budget?For a first effort, "Flywheel" is pretty good. It's actually a movie you can watch with your family. I'm sick of cringing at what Hollywood thinks my wife and kids should be exposed to.If you liked "Facing The Giants" you'll want to see the first effort of the same team. Just recently released on DVD, it's a good addition to your collection. I can't wait to see what these guys have coming up next.Inspiration wise, you wonder what YOUR church can do to impact this world. $20k is a cheap investment in changed lives.
summary: Hope For All Wanna Be Filmmakers!

reviewText: Jay Austin wants to sell you a car, and it doesn't matter to him how he does it. He is dishonest in his business, and that's exactly how he conducts his personal life as well. He is dishonest in all of his relationships even his wife and son know they can't trust him. However, as Jay works on restoring a classic 1958 Triumph TR3A convertible, he comes face-to-face with the reality that his life is spinning out of control because of the choices he has made and the way he has conducted himself in his business and in his relationships. He resolves to give his life and his business over to God and make God the "Boss," and begins the ride of his life. Alex Kendrick's convincing, no-nonsense performance as an amoral businessmen and the picture's spartan straightforward approach, with a modicum of humor, is this movie saving graces. "Flywheel" draws its title from the missing part of an engine in a vintage Triumph convertible. I enjoyed this movie, this is a movie worth watching.

reviewText: Even though this movie was produced by a church in Georgia (Sherwood Baptist), with no paid actors and on a shoestring budget, it is excellent. This is the kind of movie America (and the world) is starving for - a movie that stresses doing what is right, and helps us to realize that we all need God as our partner in life.  If the movie industry would provide the public with this type of uplifting and inspiring movie on a regular basis, they could regain much of the audience that they've alienated over the years.This movie is just as good, in its own way, as the newer Sherwood Baptist production, "Facing the Giants,"  which has done very well indeed.  "Facing the Giants" is so popular in my nearby Columbus library system that the 18 branches carry a total of 24 copies, all of which are out on loan, with a waiting list of 358 people!Think about helping both "Flywheel" and "Facing the Giants" get better exposure in your neck of the woods by doing what I did:  buy several copies of each and donate them to your local library! My local library system didn't even carry "Flywheel," but I donated one copy to them (as a start), and they are adding it to their selection and it will soon be available. However, make sure that they can and will use these copies before you put out money for these donation copies.
summary: America need more movies like this!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie has a great message.  However, you must keep in mind that it was the first movie that Sherwood made-it was on a very low budget and all of the actors were amateur volunteers.  If you are critical towards movie quality/filming, then this movie isn't for you.  If you can see past the "low-budgetness" and look at the moral of the story-then watch this movie.  I would recommend watching all 4 of Sherwood's movies, they get better & better each time.  Starting with the next movie, Facing the Giants, the quality goes up drastically.  In fact it appears to me to be just as high of quality of normal Hollywood films.  Your time will not be wasted watching all 4 of these movies-and it helps to support a ministry instead of a sick/twisted Hollywood.
